awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: CAS: Climate-Eco-friendly Biocoating for Passive Cooling of Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to reduce global warming using an innovative passive cooling technique. The project will develop an environmentally friendly, passive cooling coating that can help reduce the temperature of buildings. The coating is expected to provide energy reductions ranging from 5-25%, depending on climate and building characteristics.  The solution may reduce the need for traditional compressor-based cooling systems (e.g., air conditioners), which require a constant supply of electricity and coolants, stressing the environment through the greenhouse effect. The company expects to generate commercial revenues from both the paint-like coating featuring biocompatible passive cooling fibers and raw hydroxyapatite (HAP) fibers. Main customer target groups for the paint matrix include commercial and residential building owners that are looking for ways to lower their electric bills while lessening their negative environmental footprint.

The proposed innovation is founded on self-cleaning, fire-resistant, cooling fibers formulated with HAP. HAP cooling fibers will be integrated within a paint matrix for ease of application and cost-effectiveness. The aim is to develop and commercialize this environmentally friendly, passive cooling material as a coating with multiple functionalities. The team will identify environmentally friendly, paint-based materials within cost constraints, determine paint-fiber compatibility, and validate the cooling performance of candidate composites. The durability of the paint materials will also be confirmed. The project will focus on the design of a small-scale manufacturing line capable of producing fiber-based cooling paint at pilot scale for repeatability and field validation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this Phase I SBIR grant, Planck Energies Inc. has made substantial progress towards eco-friendly cool roof coatings. An improved method for synthesizing a highly reflective and eco-friendly cooling pigment was developed. This method reduces production costs by several orders of magnitude, while also greatly reducing material waste. The resulting calcium phosphate-based pigment maintains a solar reflectance of about 98%, making it a great choice for implementation within cool roof coatings.

Furthermore, hundreds of different prototype cool roof coatings were developed and tested. Solar reflectance indexes (SRIs) of over 120 were realized in several different formulations. These formulations also possessed outstanding outdoor durability, resisting abrasion, water, and UV exposure without losses in optical performance or mechanical stability.

Field tests with these formulations were conducted on small outdoor sheds in Texas and Massachusetts. Throughout the hot August weather, the developed eco-friendly cool roof coatings showed remarkable cooling abilities. The Planck Energies coatings kept the outer roof surface over 5 °C (9 °F) cooler than a commercial white paint and over 15 °C (27 °F) cooler than a bare metal roof. The roof coatings also showed strong resistance to intense rain and sunlight exposure during the duration of the test, again maintaining optical and mechanical performance.

Planck Energies is actively engaging with multiple organizations in the paints and coatings industry to help deliver these innovations to consumers. The eco-friendly cooling pigment – as well as the developed cool roof formulations – show great promise for reducing energy consumption and delivering life-saving cooling worldwide. Planck Energies is excited to continue the development of these green technologies.
